üìñBOOK REVIEW üìö
.
üîπBook I‚Äôve just read: ‚ÄúAugust Heat‚Äù by Camilleri
.
üîπBook I‚Äôm going to read: ‚ÄúThe black moon‚Äù by Winston Graham
.
That‚Äôs the second book Penny lent me; another italian crime novel, this time by Camilleri, that I liked more than the first one being the narration at times ironical and humorous about policemen‚Äôs stereotypes. Plus, I considered Montalbano a tough, cool guy (until I actually found out he‚Äôs already on his fifties üò±üò¶ but, whatever...). I liked his ways and temper, his cold blood during investigation and at the same time fragility and sense of remorse while looking back at his actions with a cool head. 
The plot follows the traditional crime novels pattern: it‚Äôs a very hot, muggy summer in Vigata. So hot the book reminds it to us once every page, together with Montalbano‚Äôs complaints and remedies researches. We have a friends vacation, and an unexpected, casual discover that‚Äôll make everyone go away and leave but Montalbano, who‚Äòll find himself involved in a new case, struggling with the heat, his girlfriend frail relationship, mobsters and his inner disputes and clashes. 
I liked the investigation process, the developing of the story and the ending too, it left me some interesting points to wonder on and a slight curiosity on whether keep on the saga someday... ü§îüí™üèª
.
This book was my travel companion during my Windsor-Stonehenge-Oxford tour this November; 
Now that my boyfriend has gifted me with this adorable collection of Winston Graham‚Äôs masterpieces, I definitely have to get back to read Poldark and soak into the wonderful cornish atmosphere üíï which I largely miss on my skin ... but that‚Äôs another issue üòÇ‚úàÔ∏èüíõ
Thanks @cellaibeppe for providing me with this large amount of fine reading material üòòüìö
.
#book #read #reading #winstongraham #poldark #saga #camilleri #montalbano #augustheat #crimenovel #thriller #bookstagram #booklover #bookshelf #englishliterature #englishauthor #literature #victorian #hobby #pages #books #shelf #library #freetime #bookreview

‚ñ™Ô∏èLondon / Stansted airport ‚úàÔ∏è‚ñ™Ô∏è
.
DAY#4: 02/11/19
.
Our last day. 
Departing time approaching and sadness emerging. Dad‚Äôs temper getting untenable and bad weather looming. 
This sums up pretty well our last day...how I felt was however blue and melancholic cause it was too early to leave! üòñüò¢.
We took the underground to Piccadilly Circus , entered a desolate  chinatown and had breakfast in an expensive italian caf√© just outside the Chinese quarters. We walked up to Seven Dials, the unmissable Neal‚Äôs Yard spot, and paid the British Museum a short visit, buying some souvenirs and exploring the egyptian, greek (yes! I also spotted the stolen caryatid from the Herecteion! ü§≠üò¨üòÇ), african,mexican and chinese wings most of all. At the security check (before entering) the inspectors made us unpack our bags to check them and see if we were carrying forbidden items and guess what? That made dad vary upset therefore I knew it was time to make our way back to the airport üòÇüò´
Finally we reached Tottenham Hale station and took the train to Stansted Airport where we had lunch and bought many souvenirs for our lucky nephews üòú. Since the weather in Italy was awful, the return flight hit some turbolence but we landed safely at the scheduled time üí™üèª.
Once again I shall thank London and its beautiness for offering me this pleasant refugee from every-day life. I loved the guided tour-a bit rushy ok, but still it showed me three milestones concerning english culture in a day.
.
Until next time my love üíòüá¨üáß
.
#london #uk #england #visit #explore #travel #airport #chinatown #britishmuseum #piccadilly #nealsyard #trocadero #familyvacation #walk #picoftheday #landscape #city #aroundtheworld

‚ñ™Ô∏èüåô ùïÉùïÜ‚ÑïùîªùïÜ‚Ñï , UK üá¨üáß‚ñ™Ô∏è
.
DAY#3: 01/11/19
.
Back from Richmond the weather and dad‚Äôs mood began to change: from radiant and occasionally sunny to gloomy and drizzly üòÇ‚òîÔ∏è.
We took shelter by entering the Natural History Museum and I finally met the huge blue whale skeleton which has replaced the former dinosaur! üêã
We just treated ourselves to a quick visit to the dinosaurs wing, the moon, minerals, stuffed animals and the giant sequoia tree trunk. Next, our walk followed this route:
- V&A museum, Science Museum, Royal Albert hall, Albert memorial, Kensington gardens (through Queen‚Äôs Gate), Kensington palace.
.
back to our hotel room/shower and agreed to enjoy a little of London-by-night üíò
.
Took the underground to Tower hill station, Tower of London, Tower Bridge crossed, the Shard (literally standing at its feet!) , London Bridge tube station to Covent Garden, Agatha Christie memorial, dinner at Pizza Hut, where dad found happiness and renewed spirit! üçïand I have to admit it offered us a tasty dinner, with free buffet-salad and toppings, free water and delicious chicken steaks üòú
.
#london #londonbridge #night #dinnerout #pizza #pizzahut #museums #naturalhistory #royalalberthall #kensingtongardend #kensingtonpalace #roundpond #queenvictoriastatue #familyvacation #pictureoftheday #landscape #lights #riverthames #walk #hike #visit #travel #explore #uk #england #city #toweroflondon

‚ñ™Ô∏èü¶å Richmond Park üçÅ‚ñ™Ô∏è
.
DAY#3: 01/11/19
.
Here‚Äôs some pictures capturing amazing antlers, deers herds and the largest of London‚Äôs Royal parks.
Richmond park is wild and vast, teeming with freely roaming animals and autumnal colors.
I wish I‚Äôd rent a bike to explore it since it turned out pretty proving for my dad to walk around there (even though he‚Äòll never confess it üòú).
.
#deers #antlers #horns #royalpark #richmonpark #london #england #uk #travel #visit #explore #hike #walk #autumn #autumnvibes #park #wildlife #pond #wild #animal #animallover #naturelover #colors #picoftheday #landscape #skyline #hollyhockcafe #aroundtheworld

‚ñ™Ô∏èRichmond, Surrey - England ‚ñ™Ô∏è
.
DAY#3: 01/11/19
.
On november the 1st, our destination was Richmond above all to visit its exquisite park! ü§ó I‚Äôve always been told it was lovely in autumn and since the weather was still holding on (cloudy indeed, but no sign of rain yet) we took the green line and dropped off at its last stop: Richmond.
The neighborhood was smart and neat and our walk turned out very pleasant. It was full of parks, following the river Thames, scattered with fallen leaves of every autumnal colors. A joyful sight! 
We took a coffee break at hollyhock cafe, a fairytale-like spot üçÑ and then we reached the main park!
We walked miles and miles around it, and I jumped out of my skin when I spotted the first royal deers!!! üòÆüòÆ those were unhorned, but after we crossed a lake we also saw few of them with huge, fierce horns! Wow!!! I stopped to take pics and make videos as they were grazing and horn-fighting.
Not-so-tired yet, we visited Isabella plantation and took our way back, strolling along side horses and wild animals. Once back in Richmond centre we had lunch and decided to do more exploration in London... ü•∞
.
#Richmond #uponthames #visit #park #royal #deers #wild #animals #nature #naturelover #landscape #view #autumn #leaves #fallenleaves #colors #london #uk #explore #picoftheday #familyvacation #aroundtheworld #shops

‚ñ™Ô∏è ùôæùöáùôµùôæùöÅùô≥ , Oxfordshire - England üè¥Û†ÅßÛ†Å¢Û†Å•Û†ÅÆÛ†ÅßÛ†Åø‚ñ™Ô∏è
. üîªFACTS üîª
.
- There are 39 universities in Oxford. It does not have a main campus, and its buildings and facilities are scattered throughout the city centre.
.
-After disputes between students and Oxford townsfolk in 1209, universities were suspended and some academics fled north-east to Cambridge where they established what became the University of Cambridge.
.
-The name Oxford comes from the old term 'Oxanforda' which literally meant a ford (shallow crossing) in the river where the cattle (Oxen) could cross safely.
.
-. It was there that in 1139 Geoffrey of Monmouth wrote his History of the Kings of Britain, a compilation of Arthurian legends.
.
-Oscar Wilde,attended Oxford from 1874 to 1878.
.
-Jude the Obscure (1895) by Thomas Hardy (in which Oxford is thinly disguised as "Christminster").
.
üîªPICTURESüîª
.
1üîª Radcliffe Camera
2üîª Balliol College
3üîª Trinity College
4üîªThe white horse
5üîªHistory of Science Museum with Oxford‚Äôs motto
6üîªTower of five orders
7üîªKing James I statue
8üîªExeter college 
9üîªSt Michael at the north gate tower
10üîªpretty timbered building turned into pret-a-manger
.
#oxford #city #spires #oxfordshire #england #uk #visit #travel #explore #radcliffecamera #campus #college #study #famous #culture #trip #familyvacation #picoftheday #aroundtheworld #exetercollege #museum #historyofscience #statue #tower #architecture

‚ñ™Ô∏è ùïÜùï©ùïóùï†ùï£ùïï , Odfordshire - England üë©üèª‚Äçüéìüìñ‚ñ™Ô∏è
.
DAY#2: 31/10/19
.
One hour and 20/30 minutes drive separated us from our last stop: the city of dreaming spires, the oldest university in the english-speaking world...Oxford! üéâ
Once we got off, we immediately found ourselves dipped in the student atmosphere with Balliol College standing directly across the road. There also was a tall, pointy, memorial monument and that was supposed to be our meeting point at 6.00PM. 
We made our way past St. Mary Magdalen Church and then turned left to start our guided tour with our guide giving us a few basic informations about colleges structure which reflected those of the churches either for the outside (cloisters, bell-towers...)and the insides (great hall, choirs...). He told us how many writers and famous people had been inspired  by Oxford after having studied or taught there such as  Charles Dodgson (A.K.A. Lewis Carroll), who wrote Alice in Wonderland based on a real girl named Alice Liddell. She was the daughter of the Dean at Christ Church, who with Dodgson spent much time. Other characters and elements of the book have also been based on professors, food and things the writer experienced while in Oxford!
We walked ahead, past the Trinity college on our right to come across the ‚ÄúWhite Horse‚Äù pub, from which Tolkien had drawn inspiration when describing the ‚Äúprancing pony‚Äù, where Frodo and his sidekicks meets Aragorn üòú.
We left Exeter College back on our right and then crossed the road entering this charming place, which looked like it had popped out from a fairy tale; the sun was starting to go down and the glowing lights coming from within the buildings radiated a warm, welcoming atmosphere. We had just passed by the Sheldonian Theatre [üîªpic3] when we got soaked into the historic heart of university, totally embraced by the History of Science museum (where the famous blackboard with ‚ÄúE=mc2‚Äù chalk-written on it by its very author is kept!) and the majestic buildings of the Bodleian Library [üîªvideo], with its columns and spires.
[continues below ‚¨áÔ∏è]

‚ñ™Ô∏èüóø ùïäùï•ùï†ùïüùïñùïôùïñùïüùïòùïñ, Wiltshire - England ‚ñ™Ô∏è
.
DAY#2: 31/10/19
.
Leaving Windsor behind, we drove in direction of the world‚Äôs most famous stone circle, crossing foggy plains scattered with cows grazing and several mounds and long barrows which our guide explained are part of the vast archeological area of Stonehenge. 
We parked at the visitor centre and waited for the shuttle bus to carry us to the entrance of the site, shivering everytime I got a glimpse of that magical stone circle ! ü§≠
Indeed I was thrilled, charmed by its spell and enjoying being in such a place, oozing mystical and peaceful atmosphere. I know it‚Äôs just standing stones but hey! Stonehenge‚Äôs intricate and painstaking design far surpasses all other stone circles in Britain! The weight of the stones, their positioning, the fact that‚Äôs the only stone circle in the whole world to have lintels!! The misteries and legends surrounding its purpose and the way it was built, those things make a place like Stonehenge a real thrill to me ! ü§©
Birds were nesting at the stones and a tv troup was recording and conducting an interview while I was listening to my audioguide and learning about how the sarsen stones (the bigger ones) and the bluestones (actually grey but, whatever.. üòÖ) were quarried from wales and other far away places and carried there probably by using a rolling-system and a looot of patience üòÇ . There‚Äôs no proof that Druids ever worshipped there; Stonehenge could have been a burial ground from its earliest beginnings as deposits containing human bone were found in the area. It might have also been an observatory, which allowed predictions of solstice, equinox and other celestial events also thanks to the precise position of the Heel Stone [üîªpic5]
Incredible! Just stunning! ‚òÄÔ∏è
In regard to the ‚Äúsacrifices issue‚Äù, again there‚Äôs no evidences on wheter they had occurred or not; infact, the red stains on the slaughter stone (standing outside the circle) are due to the large amount of iron. Not blood.ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
. [You can discover other notions and facts about Stonehenge by reading the comments below ‚¨áÔ∏èüí™üèª]
.
Pictures and breath of enchanted air taken, we hurried to our meeting point. It was 2.35 PM... üôÇ

‚ñ™Ô∏èüè∞ùòûùò™ùòØùò•ùò¥ùò∞ùò≥ ùò§ùò¢ùò¥ùòµùò≠ùò¶ - Windsor, Berkshire ‚ñ™Ô∏è
.
DAY#2: 31/10/19
.
On day#2 we headed to the meeting point next to Victoria station, where we were joined by our guide, driver and travel companions. 
Our first stop was due in Windsor, just a short 30‚Äô drive away from London during which the young guide bud gave us some info. 
I didn't get to catch every word he said mostly because we had to listen to him through headphones and he really had a strange, asthmatic way of talking üòï [By the way, what I learnt from him during our bus ride you can read it in the comments below ‚¨áÔ∏èüí™üèª]
.
Once there we had a few time (about 1h15) to get through the security checks and freely wander around the castle, primarily exploring the State apartments, the Doll House üîªpic2/ St.George Chapel (where Meghan and Harry married not long ago üéâ as many other royal couples had; and where Henry VIII ‚Äòs grave is placed) and the change of the guards, taking place between 11 and 11.30 in front of the chapel.
The state rooms were magnificent, too bad pictures were forbidden there because what stood in front of my eyes really impressed me a lot! I felt like this one was even more refined and pomp than the other castles I visited. Exception made, probably, for Hampton Court üòÖ. No wonder why Queen Elizabeth and the royal family adore it. [However, to have a glimpse of those apartments and the chapel just click the link in the comments below‚¨áÔ∏èüí™üèª]
Windsor is the biggest still-inhabited castle, hence we had to rush from room to room to be able to fully explore it. Next we entered St. George Chapel, not before we could appreciate its gothic features and decoration on the exteriors. We attended the changing of the guards ceremony and hurried to the meeting point where we were given a free lunch pack ü•∞
.
#windsorcastle #windsor #queen #royal #royalfamily #royalwedding #stgeorgechapel #changingoftheguards #towers #park #landscape #view #explore #visit #travel #walk #hike #orderofthegarter #tour #familyvacation #ceremony #picoftheday #gardens #dollhouse

‚ñ™Ô∏è ùìõùì∏ùì∑ùì≠ùì∏ùì∑ , England üá¨üáß‚ñ™Ô∏è
.
DAY#1: 30/10/19
.
The countdown to my annual visit to the City ended precisely on the 30th of October, exactly one day following my sick-night which I spent vomiting and therefore sleepless üòÖ.
By the time I‚Äôd reached Stansted Airport, however, I could say I had fully recovered and hence I was ready and excited to start walking, visiting and taking pics around my favorite main city.
This time I brought both my parents with me; this fact made the whole thing much more special to me, especially because my dad succeeded in NOT-complaining and whinnying for at least 2 and a half days and that was utterly unexpected! üòÇüí™üèªüéâ
From Stansted we got off the train at Tottenham Hale and took the underground there to Victoria station, namely the nearest tube stop to the Golden Tours offices, where we finally booked the ‚ÄúWindsor/Stonehenge/Oxford‚Äù tour for the following day! ü§©.
From there, out walking route goes as follows:  royal mews, buckingham palace, st james‚Äôs park, the mall, admiralty arch, trafalgar square, national gallery, st martin in the field, the strand, somerset house, twinings (obviously I stocked up on teabags), royal courts of justice, temple church, st paul‚Äôs cathedral,monument, london bridge, southwark cathedral, borough market, golden hinde, bankside walk -Shakespeare‚Äôs globe, tate modern, millennium bridge, oxo tower, gabriel‚Äôs wharf, festival piers, jubilee gardens, london eye, london dungeon, sea life, westminster bridge, big ben and parliament, parliament square, westminster abbey.
We had already walked many miles when we eventually agreed that time had come to make our way towards the hotel by St James‚Äôs park tube station.
Our hotel was admittedly rather shabby and unkept but, on the other hnd, it was located in a quite, peaceful neighborhood, pretty close to the Madame Tousseauds, the Sherlock Holmes Museum and several tube stations, making it very suitable for its purpose in my planned trip.
Bags dropped, we went out again as the weather was pleasant and we wanted to make the best of these few days. We passed by the S.Holmes Museum and then headed to Oxford St. ...
.
[continues in the comments below ‚¨áÔ∏è]

‚ñ™Ô∏èRocca della Verruca/Verruca Fortress üè∞‚õ∞‚ñ™Ô∏è
.
26/10/19
.
Long time since I decided to get up there and finally was able to do so this Saturday. Definitely well worth the 1 hour hike through an unusual environment tragically  formed after last summer‚Äôs arson, surrounded by burnt down trees but at the same time sprouts of new shrubs! üåø
Pretty tired, we had a lovely pic-nic around the remains of the Rocca before we took our way down.
Here‚Äôs some info about this place I strongly recommend you visit:
.
‚ÄúThe Verruca Fortress is found between the municipalities of Calci and Vicopisano, at the summit of Monte Verruca in the eastern range of the Pisan mountains. The Verruca Fortress has been strategically important ever since the time of the Pisan Republic. Its privileged position allowed it to function as a lookout post, able to survey Pisa and the castle of Vicopisano.
Sources testify to the existence of a Verrucca fortress even before the year 1000. 
The rock was later the scene of numerous sieges and skirmishes between Pisa and Florence, which seems to have even employed Leonardo da Vinci to bolster the castle's defences.‚Äù
.
#roccadellaverruca #calci #verrucafortress #hike #walk #climb #mount #pisa #pisanmountains #friends #sunnyday #nature #naturelover #landscape #view #picnic #happy #stroll #path #animals

üìñBOOK REVIEW üìö
.
üîπBook I‚Äôve just read: ‚ÄúThe temptation of forgiveness‚Äù by Donna Leon
.
üîπBook I‚Äôm going to read: ‚ÄúAugust heat‚Äù by Camilleri
.
Lately, after my acquaintance with an english woman (a friend of mum), I‚Äôve been throwing myself into new kind of lectures which means I‚Äôm taking a wee break from classics and historical novels. Hence, these two books up in the headline, they had been borrowed and suggested me by my new lovely friend Penny üòä .
The reading of Leon‚Äôs crime novel gave me the chance to make a comparison between her and Christie‚Äôs novels and find out some interesting and blatant differences.
In ‚Äúthe temptation of forgiveness‚Äù we have a more realistic and methodical way to deal with an investigation, if I can say that. I mean, maybe that‚Äôs because the narration follows an italian detective working in Venice that I find it more familiar and relatable to actual facts. We often see him walking around the city, dealing with his family and partners, checking datas and files, making assumptions and failing, questioning suspects... he‚Äôs not as mysterious and cryptic as Miss Marple or Poirot might be. 
He sometimes find himself torn between what is good and what is not, what the right thing to be done might be, about the consequences; frequently the most righteous and fast way to solve issues may appear to be illegal, or it may require to turn a blind eye, to bend rules.
Finally, I can declare my predilection for Agatha Christie‚Äôs plot twists and cliffhangers. Undoubtedly the long list of suspects , their meticulous description and the delineation of their traits fascinates me more. üá¨üáß‚ô•Ô∏è
However, let‚Äôs now start this other novel and see...
.
#book #booklover #read #reading #travel #travelcompanion #athens #greece #thetemptationofforgiveness #donnaleon #seconhandbook #bookshelf #bookshop #crimenovel #thriller

‚ñ™Ô∏èAthens / back home üá¨üá∑‚ñ™Ô∏è
.
18/09/19
.
It was still dark when I walked out my hotel to venture in Monastiraki Square. Trolley and backpacks, metro tickets to the airport and there I was, on my way to the end of this journey. 
I arrived at the airport after a 45 mins train ride, then checked in (not without problems üòÖ) at the Aegean automatic machine and finally had a proper breakfast. 
The flight with Aegean took off at 8.10 AM, it was relaxing and pleasant and I‚Äôd been kindly offered breakfast (again!) by the staff. I landed after approximately 2hours and 15 minutes and here there are some selfies I took each day with the other half of my exploration group, which is to say my misadventures pal, my knee-injured trekker, my greek God of souvlaki‚Äôs skewers and tzatziki sauce, my dearest @cellaibeppe ü•∞üíô.
Farewell Greece. Next time it‚Äôll be islands turn. üòÖüèù
.
#athens #greece #travel #explore #visit #picoftheday #landscape #selfie #view #aroundtheworld #airport #boyfriend #travelblog #diary #adventure #greek #traveller #wander #holidays #flight #home

‚ñ™Ô∏èAthens, ŒëŒ∏ŒÆŒΩŒ± -Greece üá¨üá∑‚ñ™Ô∏è
.
DAY#7: 17/09/19
.
For this morning I arranged a plan to visit three destinations in Athen‚Äôs neighborhoods:
-Niu Filadelfia park üîªpic2 , with its mill and quiet atmosphere, an area inhabited by so many joggers and runners üí™üèª
-The olympionic area üîªpic 3 -The theatre of Shadow Puppet museum üîªpic4, a free museum- exhibition of a famous puppeteer‚Äôs works. I really appreciate this little digression :) .
.
At lunch time i was back in central Athens, I therefore followed Niko‚Äôs indications to get to this ‚Äúrestaurant‚Äù at the 9th floor of an anonymous building facing Syntagma Square, where the owners steadily had a table set up for me out on the terrace, offering me a free, incredible view over the city, the Acropolis and Parthenon on the right and Syntagma Square on my left. I ate and drank so much for a very cheap price and everything was freshly made in the kitchen inside just behind me. I was the only costumer at the beginning and this gave a much mysterious aura to the place but also peace and tranquility to my senses. .
Restored by this extraordinary culinary experience, I started wandering around the city which by this time I was starting to know quite well. Streets, shops, bars...they‚Äôve come and gone before my eyes so many times during the week...
I bought my last gifts and shirts and decided to take a tea break at ‚Äúthree old books cafe‚Äù then headed to: acropolis museum (just to see the excavations underneath it), philopappo‚Äôs hill (looking for an open air theatre), the surrounding areas of Acropolis (at the Odeonüîªpic 5 they were organizing a concert or something) and finally decided to go up the Areopagus üîªpic 6,7,8,9, a prominent rock at Acropolis feet which in classical times functioned as a court; it‚Äôs here Ares was supposed to have been tried by the gods for the murder of Poseidon's son.
.
Shower made, bags packed, fast dinner matched with ice-cream and I was ready to sleep my last greek night, alarm set for 4 AM...
.
#athens #greece #attiki #athina #trip #travel #explore #visit #walk #hike #picoftheday #landscape #food #view #shadowpuppet #olympionic #niufiladelfia #areopagus #hill #trekjing #odeon #greek #folk #aroundtheworld

‚ñ™Ô∏èMeteora (ŒúŒµœÑŒ≠œâœÅŒ±), Kalabaka - Greece üá¨üá∑‚ñ™Ô∏è
.
DAY#6:16/09/19
.
While planning my greek adventure, I wanted to include various bus and train trips, plus Santorini. That was the idea. I picked several destinations such as Mycenae, Corinth, Delphi and-the most unlikely -due to the long distance- Meteora. 
However, as things started to get complicated, timetables were not to be trusted, direct buses were not to be found and so on.. I came up with the fact that Meteora‚Äôs day trip with a long train ride was actually the most likely to be achieved.
Initially, I choose the 14th for the visit, following the disappointing Santorini‚Äôs affair but when I got to the station, the ticket vendor told me there was no more a 8.20 train cause, since a while, it has been anticipated at 7.20 and I had just missed it üò´. Not a lucky day-that day.
.
To reach Kalabaka the train took 5 hours and I had a standing ticket which means all the seats were taken üòÖ to my good luck an old woman let me sit next to her and that seat was never requested!
Once in Kalabaka I drove up to the monasteries area with a taxi whose driver insisted to sell me the full tour to make the best of the day. I refused,obviously, because i wanted to walk my own way and explore freely even if I knew I hadn‚Äôt that much time as to take it easy. Hence, once dropped off i started my long hike that allowed me to spot every six orthodox monasteries (exception made for St.Stephen, which I don‚Äôt recall ü§î) built on immense rocky pillars creating a unique landscape and a breathtaking scene! -Monastery of Holy Trinity üîªpic 3,6 was the first one I set my eyes on
-Monastery of Varlaam was the one I entered in, where I had to wear a gown to cover my pants ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
-Monastery of Great Meteoron üîªpic10 was the last one on my pilgrimage and the largest one. 
The other still working monasteries were:
-Rousanou (a nunnery)
-St.Nicholas Anapausas
-St.Stephen
.
6 more miles and I was back in Kalabaka...a long way after all the climbs I‚Äôd done, but still a pleasant stroll, soaked in a timeless space, surely one of the most amazing spot in Greece.
.

‚ñ™Ô∏èAthens, Greece üá¨üá∑‚ñ™Ô∏è
.
DAY#5: 15/09/19
.
I woke up in that heavenly place and super-comfy resort, packed my bags and bid Sounion goodbye from my bus. 
It was Sunday morning, supposedly the best time to catch the changing of the guards ceremony in Sintagma Square üîªpic 1,5 . I prayed the bus to speed up as it was a bit late (the ceremony supposed to take place starting from 11 o clock if I go no wrong) but when I got off of it, to my genuine surprise, a crowd of people was still around the square, clearly waiting for something. I didn‚Äôt realize what exactly was going on but after some time a band started to play and a group of folks (politicians, men and women in traditional clothes, men carrying flags and so on...) arrived and marched at the square! üòØ a strange ritual began, each politician receiving a banner (or something like thatü§î) I assumed it might have been a sort of celebration, I cannot say for sure, not even now ü§î
.
My new hotel was a bit closer to Monastiraki square, in a far better neighborhood üòÖ it hearten me a lot to have finally switched to a different accomodation...
Then, I made up my mind as to plan a great journey for the day to come [find out more about it in my next postüîúüí™üèª] and just spent the rest of my day exploring random buildings in town (Athens Cathedralüîªpic 6 ),cocktail bars (Noel, The Clumsiesüîªpic8 ) and wandering the main streets doing some shopping. I also bumped into a book festival at the National Gardens and looked for some of Lord Byron‚Äôs works, although the only thing I found of his was his statueüîªpic 7. The Zappeion hosted a modern art exhibition which wasn‚Äôt free to go, but allowed me to enter the building and appreciate some fine architecture of it.
To finish off, I had dinner at Yiasemiüîªpic 9,10 sitting on those picturesque stairs, as thronged with people as they could be and still I could feel positive vibes there, being it a vibrant spot of Athens (peaceful) night life and a very typical supplier of local food.
.

.
DAY#4: 14/09/19
.
My alarm clock was set so early it even anticipated the rooster crowing but my weariness was overwhelmed by a thrilled mood since I really want a break from the city life and escape to that paradise-alike island which is Santorini. 
However, as I‚Äôve hinted at in my latest post, all cruises were canceled due to weather conditions and strong winds...
Helpless and so tired, with my hopes crushed, I wad incapable to think straight and look for a solution. There wasn‚Äôt much left to do back in Athens neither had I booked an hotel for that night so I left the Pieaeus area to get to the centre again with my trolley, my backpack, my sac and my camera with me üò∞ two bags were also hanging down from below my eyes. 
I walked up to explore Anafiotika, a neighborhood with white old-fashioned houses, narrow streets and took some pics there üîªpic2.
Then I decided to listen to what, the day before, I‚Äôve been suggested to do by the owner of ice-cream shop ‚Äúil cremino‚Äù; she recommended a day trip to Cape Sounion by bus and there I headed! 
It was mid-morning, about 10:20 when I got on the bus, unable to take some rest, afraid I won‚Äôt find a place to stay the night there. Not a cheap one at least.
Crossing the Attika‚Äôs Riviera and enjoying some sea-views for the first time and two hours later I dropped off to be stuck by the strongest gusts of wind I‚Äôve ever experienced! üí® I couldn‚Äôt even appreciate the wonderful temple of Poseidon so exhausted I was! 
The nearest hotel (a restort, to be preciseüîªpic3,4) was 20/25 mins of walk far, all the way headwinds, obviously. It was sophisticated, chick, and modern and it wasn‚Äôt cheap. Nevertheless, by far against my principles and not light hearted, it was there I chose to accomodate and to sleep till 4.00 o‚Äôclock in the evening.
Admittedly, it brought me back to life üòÖ. Comfort and relax were exactly what I needed and after the receptionists showed me a shortcut to the temple, I made my way up to explore it! 
The Temple of Poseidon üîªpic 1,5,6 stands tall and grand on an hilltop, hit by sun and wind and a conspicuous number of tourists.
.

‚ñ™Ô∏èAthens-Greece üá¨üá∑‚ñ™Ô∏è
.
DAY#3: 13/09/19
.
My main aim that day was to reach the port of Piraeus and to book a cruise to Santorini, due to depart the following day. So, I took the green line of the metro and did it all; too bad a tremendous news would hit me on day#4 so that it turned out to be a trip for naught. ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è [read day#4 to find outüîú].
However, I continued exploring Athens, in particular, here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve visited :
-The kerameikos (with its cemetery, burial monuments and its museum) üîªpic 2
-museum of greek folk musical instruments üîªpic 6
-
And after a short coffee break in Yiasemi üîªpic 7,8,9 , I headed north, to the National Archeological museum üîªpic 3 , were many renowned pieces of art were to be spotted around every corner! To begin with, just a few step ahead from the entrance, you see the magnificent mask of Agamemnon üîªpic 4, which you surely must‚Äôve seen at least once in your history books!
Other highlights include The Antikythera Ephebe, the Artemision bronze, the jockey of Artemision...
- The statue of Athena Nike üîªpic 1, placed in a park next to Victoria metro station, the one I entered to get back to Athens city centre and have an early dinner in one of the many restaurants in Monastiraki square that treated me with greek salad as starter üîªpic10 and pita gyros + souvlaki (sort of skewers) and other grilled meat to end with. They also offered me the dessert ü•≥.
.

DAY#2: 12/09/19
.
Day #2 was by far the most trying (as I walked around 30 kms up and down the Acropolis) and at the same time rewarding in terms of views and historical elements. As suggested in many guides and sites, I headed my way up the Acropolis (meaning ‚Äúthe high town‚Äù) some minutes before its opening hour in order to avoid the queues and have some time to visit and enjoy it in ease and peace, before the crowds of tourists start to assail it.
The temple I liked the most up there was ‚Äî with no doubt‚Äî the Erechtheion, the one with the Caryatids üîªpic4. The Parthenon comes next, obviously üíõüîªpic1,5.
Myths and legend, battles for the hegemony of Athens and its surroundings are to be found here! To learn more about ‚ÄúAthena and Poseidon myth‚Äù read the comment below! ‚§µÔ∏èüí™üèª
Other things I visited that dat were:
-Odeon of Herodes Atticus üîªpic2
-Athena Nike‚Äôs temple üîªpic3
-theatre of Dyonisus üîªpic6 -Adrian‚Äôs arch + Temple of Zeus Olympus üîªpic7‚¨ÜÔ∏è
-Philopappo‚Äôs hill üîªpic7‚¨áÔ∏è + prisons of Socrates -Athenian Agora (ancient agora) + temple of Hephaestus + stoa of Attalos (museum) üîªpic8
-Roman Agora + tower of the winds üîªpic9
-Adrian‚Äôs library
-Acropolis museum (where I got the chance to actually admire the original marbles of the Acropolis since what we have up there are (almost all) copies and restructured parts. I saw the original Caryatids, exception made for one of them that is kept and displayed...(drumrolls) in the British Museum! üòÅ greeks are a bit mad about this fact, and I feel them, admittedly üòÖ. üîªpic10
-Benaki‚Äôs museum -National gardens-turtle‚Äôs pond

Finally I had dinner out at Glykis. Good, typical food and nice atmosphere in the neighborhood of Plaka.
.

.
DAY #1: 11/09/19
.
Time to tell another story! My greek adventure started as soon as I landed at the airport l, took the green line at the metro and drop off in Monastiraki square üîªpic 2: there, I took my first glance (followed by a long, astonished stare) of the mighty Acropolis, the ‚Äúhigh town‚Äù that overlooked and dominated the city.
What came and how I felt next was actually - strongly in breach of my first impression; the walk from Monastiraki to my accomodation showed me - in fact - the other side of the coin: a city utterly splattered with graffiti, high level of degradation in the streets, large number of beggars and noisy thugs to be found everywhere... it made me very unhappy and worried and had me elaborating an alternative way to get to the city centre in order to avoid the worst neighborhoods üò∞. So, I swallowed these unpleasant thoughts and headed to Syntagma square which is to say the Parliament Square, garrisoned by two guards in typical uniform, standing in front of the Monument to the Unknown Soldier. üîª pics 4
Other things I visited on my first day were:
-The National Gardens
-Panathenaic stadium (were I refreshed my memory with the Battle of Marathon‚Äôs legend and could see all the Olympic torches exhibited) üîªpics 1,6
-Lycabettus Hill (a very steep hill, once climbed it rewarded me with unique views over Athens and its surroundings)üîª pics 7,8,9,10
üîªpic 3 is ‚ÄúThe kooks‚Äù, a little oasi of colors and peace placed very close to my hotel. I stopped to have an afternoon meal there after I dropped bags in my room. Quite expensive, as it had waiters in costume and all sort of ornaments (not to mention a fanciful selection of desserts jn their menu).
As for the dinner I didn‚Äôt mean to risk, venturing out at late hours, hence I picked a greek salad in a restaurant-bar next to the metro station and ate it once I got back in my room.
.

üìöBOOK REVIEWüìñ
.
üîπBook I‚Äôve just read: ‚ÄúWarleggan‚Äù by Winston Graham
.
üîπBook I‚Äôm going to read: ‚ÄúThe temptation of forgiveness‚Äù by Donna Leon
.
Ok, I‚Äôll use this wonderful, postcard-alike picture of Levant Mines to frame the upcoming review. ‚ô•Ô∏è
.
Warleggan is the 4th book of the Poldark saga;
We have in its title the same name of the main villain of the serie‚Äîwhich is George Warleggan‚Äî and it already suggest, even before we can turn the first page, that a lot of tremendous, inauspicious things will happen.
Family Poldark, after the birth of their second son Jeremy, faces off with a marriage crisis; we have an unfortunate tragedy at the mine and a consequent, unexpected announce from Elizabeth that would lead Ross to some dreadful, shameful behaviors.
When I first watched the show I couldn‚Äôt believe my eyes and felt disgusted! Demelza‚Äôs walls begins to crumble and so does her respect for the man she thought to be so righteous and fair and she eventually tries to seek comfort and vengeance in her own way, soon realizing she had made a mistake and changing her mind.
I loved how Graham handled the whole situation; how he described and had the characters show their emotions and feelings, from disgust, to anger, pride, doubt and forgiveness. I loved one of Ross‚Äô final speeches about ‚Äúidealized love‚Äù and seeing him -somehow- making amends.
 It was an heavy blow for me and it required a very strenuous effort to get over that part of the book!
However, we also have good deeds from a deus ex machina anonymous benefactor, a complex, growing character as unpredictable as it could be! And Ross will find a way to pay his debt to him/her , and I was so glad about it ‚Äòcause it‚Äôll mend an unhappy, unfair situation!
I won‚Äôt spread any further information or notions about this novel and I‚Äôll take a break from the saga to start the reading of a crime novel kindly loaned to me by an english friend üß°
.
